name: Champion of the Tribes - Barbarian 16 / CoT 22 / Rogue 2
author: Kane

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hail, ECBers!

This build was a result of campgod's request for a level 40 version of a level 30 build in a recent build-request thread. It's WAY DIFFERENT from its counterparts, so it definitely deserves a thread. The idea is to make a hero of the tribes. Someone who would instil fear in the enemy, while being very efficient in combat.

The 3 builds that use this class combo on the ECB (strangely enough there are only 3 considering how GOOD the combo is) are quite similar to each other in a few aspects, but none is close to this one. Let's have a look at them, shall we?

Dwarf o' the North by DarkStar27909 is a well-conceived Devcritter, with EDR 3, Terrifying Rage and Mighty Rage. Still, it only has 42 AB due to the EDR focus.

Storm Knight of the Horned Lands by grizzled_dwarflord is strangely the one closest to this one, but he also goes for EDR in his build, and way more Rogue levels than this one. His AB is also 42.

The Brash Adventurer-Hero by Xylophone is an unoptimized toon with focus in RP that also goes for EDR 3 and Mighty Rage, but no Devcrit.

So, these three builds have something in common with our guy, but also many differences. First of all, we don't go for EDR here because things will be running AWAY from us, not towards us, and with our incredible TR DC you bet they'll fail! Still, there are those fear-immune monsters and monsters who are higher level and will only be penalized, but still be able to attack us. Against those, we don't tank as efficiently, but we do very good damage, and we have DevCrit. None of the other builds goes for more than 10 CoT levels, which we do, and none of them has enough CHA to use Divine Wrath. Our AB is 2 points higher and our TR DC reaches an incredible 65!. Our saves are significantly higher as well, since we have 22 CoT levels. We have Devcrit on a Scimitar, UMD to keen it, and a huge Fortitude save, so guess who's winning a battle of devcritters? WE are! With CON gear, Rage increases and buffs, we can get our Fort up to 43, with our Divine Wrath, we can cap it once a day. This character is a beautiful high-save TRing, DevCritting, UMDing monster with the Taunt / Expertise combo, high AB, and a once-per-day GOD mode that lasts for up to 9 rounds with the correct gear.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: The saves bonus from CoT counts towards the +20 cap, as do equipment and Spellcraft. If you get +11 from 22 levels of CoT and +8 from Spellcraft, that leaves only +1 that you can get from equipment, but you CAN get +6 Fortitude from boosting CON +12. Interestingly, the CHA saves boost from Paladin or Blackguard does not count towards that +20 cap.

Hi Stag!

Have you ever used Terrifying Rage? I have on WoG and they do run around like crazy, but you have Barbarian Movement Speed Increase, so you run faster. However, someone said in one of the topics here that it's not how it works in default NWN, that they'd in fact be stunned instead. The point of Terrifying Rage is that it's pretty much irresistible, so anything that is lower level than you will run and therefore not hit you. It's good to not get hit, right? Those of higher level will suffer penalties when they attack you,

Thundering Rage is shit, because it just enhances criticals. I'm aware that you think criticals are the best thing that could ever happen to a meleer, but they aren't: AB is! That mindset will evolve as you delve deeper into the game. Adding a few points of damage when you crit is not as useful as adding a few points of damage when you hit and hitting more often. When you start facing non-pathetic AC monsters, you'll also start critting a lot less, which will make you revise the thought that WM is such a useful class with only 7 levels (been there, done that). Not just because sometimes they'll be imune to crits when they have 10 PM levels or are undead, construct or simply custom-made to be immune, but because you'll need to hit them on the second attack (the one which defines if a threat will in fact be a critical hit or not) to actually crit them. If you can't hit their ACs except on 20s, then they'll be effectively uncrittable for your toon. But I digress. Thundering rage is a wasted feat such as Overwhelming Critical. The only reason you take the latter is to get Devastating Critical, otherwise it'd be completely ignorable.

Good luck with your friend. I'd take him through Aielund, man! That story is 10000000000 TIMES MORE INTERESTING than the OC's (A Metropolis like Neverwinter creating an academy to recruit a level 1 hero??? LOL! WTF kind of story is that? It does evolve into something better, but that beginning is sufferable!). Aielund has suspense, drama, twists and turns, politics (which the OCs totally lack) and then turns into an epic at the appropriate moment. At level one you are (as you should be) a fetch-boy doing errands for people in exchange for a few coins. Trust me bro, you'll never want to go back once you try it!

Take it EZ!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
As far as the ability spread, I don't see an issue, Stagmeister.  So your Divine Wrath will last 2 rounds per day instead of 3?  Meh.  And your CHA skills suffer by 1.  Again, meh.  Your first rogue dump should be moved back one to still get UMD modified to 25.  The last one is fine to cast all scrolls reliably... unless you feel you need to reach a class item value over 1M gold, then move that one back one as well.

Then again, you could trade those 2 epics in for Great CHA to reach the same levels, ability-wise, that the human version does. 

TBH, building around Divine Wrath has never been a priority for me where resting is limited.  But it does look good on paper. 

If it were me, though, I would eat the slight CHA decreases and maybe focus in epic taunt skill since this toon will be doing lots of that anyway.  Else, just a couple more Grt STR for an AB/dmg bump.  Pre-epic, Called arm shots are a way to increase your AC without reducing your native AB.  It's looking like you'd be needing a combo of taunting and something like that to avoid spending your career locked in expertise mode hoping to connect with somewhat pedestrian AB 39 vs. focused Concentration high-CON foes.

Would I be correct in thinking (from your final sentence) that, regardless of your helpful comments, you're not over-enamoured with this one?

 
Not at all.  Human or half-orc should be equally effective.  I'm just not a proponent of fighting with an AB nerf i.e. Expertise.  It's not my playstyle to wade into mobs.  I prefer to use methods to isolate and then incapacitate one enemy at a time.  But for the berzerkers out there, this one looks like a lot of fun to play. 

You just need the right environment and situation for raging to work well.  I see ranged mobs posing a major problem since neither the terror nor the taunt will help control them.  Now, if you could find a Greater Archer's belt and a Greater Brawler's, archers and slingers wouldn't cause so much of a threat.  But maybe Aeilund doesn't trigger nasty ranged encounters like that?
